results.title: Heavy traffic
results.creator_credit: Film Creations, Steve Krantz and Ralph Bakshi
results.brief_description: Where’s it all going and where does it lead us? What is life all about? Michael, a struggling cartoonist living with his part Italian part Jewish parents is searching for artistic inspiration in the seedy environment around him - a violent, sexually perverse and polluted one. Reclusive and introspective, Michael makes an unsuccessful pitch to get his work off the ground and is forced into numerous disastrous encounters with prostitutes by friends in an attempt to prove his manhood. It’s barkeep Carole who earns his affections however as well as introducing him to a life of crime. Beginning and ending with live action, Bakshi’s film following “Fritz the cat” (1972) is mainly animated in its portrayal of a seedy, disturbing, yet artistically rich milieu of New York City circa 1970s. Cast includes: Joseph Kaufmann, Beverly Hope Atkinson, Frank DeKova, Terri Haven.

results.title: Heavenly creatures
results.creator_credit: Wingnut Films, Jim Booth and Peter Jackson
results.brief_description: Set in the 1950’s in New Zealand, this film is based on a true story that shocked the nation at the time. New arrival Juliet Hulme (Kate Winslet) quickly befriends the quiet Pauline Parker (Melanie Lynskey) at their conservative school in Christchurch. Although their backgrounds are very different, the two girls are both creative and intelligent writers, and form a close friendship which gradually becomes more and more obsessive. Together, they create a fantasy world peopled by characters who become very real for both of them. Their parents are increasingly disturbed by the obsessive nature of their relationship, and take steps to separate them. This leads to the girls plotting a horrendous crime to ensure they remain together.

results.title: Heaven can wait
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Warren Beatty and Buck Henry
results.brief_description: At a peak in his career LA Rams quarterback Joe Pendleton (Warren Beatty) is erroneously summoned to heaven by an over-zealous escort (co-director Buck Henry). Mr Jordan, a senior official in heaven, (James Mason) seeks to set things in order by offering Joe a place back on earth in the body of another mortal. After seeing environmental lobbyist Betty Logan (Julie Christie) Joe decides to inhabit the body of Leo Farnsworth, a rich amoral industrialist who is in danger from his murderous wife (Dyan Cannon) and her lover (Charles Grodin). When Joe decides to get Pendleton’s body into shape he engages the services of his old coach in order to do so. This comedy was Warren Beatty’s directorial debut and he has great fun as Pendleton/Farnsworth. A fairly light romantic comedy/fantasy, “Heaven can wait” is a remake of “Here comes Mr Jordan” (1941) and was a big hit in 1978. Winner of one Academy Award in 1979 for Best art direction, the film was nominated for seven others.

results.title: Heaven's gate
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Joan Carell and Michael Cimino
results.brief_description: Heaven’s gate is one of the most talked-about films in cinema history and based on events which occurred in Wyoming in 1892 when ruthless ranchers decided to kill starving immigrants who had been stealing cattle. Kris Kristofferson and Christopher Walken play lawman and hitman on opposite sides of the struggle, who share the love of Ella, played by Isabelle Huppert. The original film was cut by 70 minutes and was never acclaimed in the United States as it was in Europe. This version is presented in its entirety and has compelling performances by the supporting cast of John Hurt, Jeff Bridges and Sam Waterston and locational shoots of breathtaking beauty.

results.title: Heaven's burning
results.creator_credit: Dup Art, Helen Leake, Al Clark and Craig Lahiff
results.brief_description: Midori (Yuki Kudoh) is a young Japanese bride, who, despising her new husband, decides to flee him on their wedding night. Faking her own kidnapping, and stranded in Sydney, Midori is then the victim of a real kidnap attempt during a violent bank robbery. Shw ends up on the road with the handsome getaway driver Colin (Russell Crowe), who saves her from execution at the hands of his cohorts, betraying them in the process. Pursued by the police, Midori’s enraged husband and Colin’s murderous gang, Colin and Midori flee towards the outback. En route the pair meet a slew of eccentric characters, attend a B and S ball and have a variety of experiences, which unites them romantically. “Heaven’s burning” is a road movie, and typically of the Australian genre, has the action contained within a deterministically peculiar outback culture. Midori’s ethnicity serves as a conduit on which to channel a range of unoriginal Aussie stereotypes, as well as highlighting racism and cultural intolerance. The film is a mix of genres - romance, crime flick, thriller - and is slavish in its desire to appear offbeat and original. Cast also includes Kenji Isomura, Ray Barrett and Robert Mammone.

results.title: Heathers
results.creator_credit: New World Pictures, Cinemarque Entertainment, Denise Di Novi and Michael Lehmann
results.brief_description: This black comedy about high school politics, teenage suicide and trendy cliques, focuses on the ‘Heathers’, three of the prettiest and most popular rich girls at Westerbury High School, home of preppies, nerds and trendies. They set the trends, make the rules and devise ways of making life hell for the other students. That is until Heather No.4 who is really a Veronica, (Winona Ryder), teams up with her boyfriend, JD, a rebellious new student (Christian Slater), to change all the rules and seek revenge. An ultimate revenge fantasy which has become a “cult” movie. Also stars Shannen Doherty.

results.title: Heat and dust
results.creator_credit: Merchant Ivory Productions, Ismail Merchant and James Ivory
results.brief_description: A young English woman journeys to India to explore the mysterious and scandalous past of her Great-aunt sixty years ago. Both succumb to the beauty of the land and its people and become pregnant. Nevertheless, they remain outsiders in a land they can never fully comprehend. Stars Julie Christie, Greta Scacchi and Madhur Jaffrey.

results.title: Heat
results.creator_credit: Monarchy Enterprises B. V., Regency Entertainment (USA), Michael Mann and Art Linson
results.brief_description: Neil McCauley (Robert De Niro) is a professional. He is meticulous and cautious. He also is a professional robber. After a successful heist, LA cop Vincent Hanna (Al Pacino) is on McCauley’s trail and out to stop him. The two are soon caught in an epic battle and yet they recognise that they are actually essentialy the same. Michael Mann’s “Heat” is a rivetting action film which also attempts to examine in some depth the lives of the film’s characters, in particular Vincent and Neil as well as the other members of his team. By casting dynamic actors like De Niro and Pacino in the lead roles, as well as Val Kilmer and John Voight in supporting roles, the focus on character remains engaging in the midst of the explosive violence of the action sequences which drive the film along.

results.title: Hearts of darkness: a filmmaker's apocalypse
results.creator_credit: ZM Productions, George Zaloom, Les Mayfield, Fax Bahr, George Hickenlooper and Eleanor Coppola
results.brief_description: The making of “Apocalypse now” was almost the breaking of famed director Francis Ford Coppola. For three years Coppola drove and dragged his actors, including Robert Duvall, Martin Sheen, Marlon Brando, and his crew through torturous conditions to complete his epic portrayal of the Vietnam War. Recreating the savagery of war left its mark - Sheen overcame a heart attack to finish the film and Coppola privately questioned his sanity. This riveting, funny and at times shocking film charts the progress of Coppola’s dream, which he personally funded to completion. It is brutally honest and includes improvisation, often drug-induced, which made it to the big screen as “brilliant performances”. Features exclusively restored footage previously deleted from “Apocalypse now”, “Hearts of darkness” is a tragedy, comedy and disaster rolled into one.

results.title: Hearts in Atlantis
results.creator_credit: Castle Rock Entertainment, NPV Entertainment, Village Roadshow Pictures, Kerry Heysen and Scott Hicks
results.brief_description: A nostalgic film set in small town America of the 1960s about maturation and the loss of innocence. Bobby is an eleven-year-old boy feeling the stigma of being from a financially strapped one-parent family. One summer a mysterious boarder Ted Brautigan (Anthony Hopkins) comes to live in the upstairs part of the house and wins over Bobby, if not his suspicious mother, Liz. It is gradually revealed that Ted has psychic powers and sinister men in dark suits are pursuing him. Bobby, in need of a father figure, is drawn into Ted’s confidence, working for him, and absorbing Ted’s wisdom. Ted assists Bobby with difficult life matters - his first kiss, trust in others, and lessons in disappointment. Structured as a flashback, “Hearts in Atlantis” has a tone not unlike a darkly themed episode of “The Wonder years.” Hicks peppers a pedestrian screenplay, laden with symbolic diatribes, with 60s hits, an expressive score, and an eye for period detail. Hope Davis puts in an understated performance as Liz - a woman who struggles with her financial situation, whilst fending off her lecherous boss. Directed by Scott Hicks (Shine, Snow falling on cedars).
